content:
The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" also amends income levels and sets a ceiling on investment insurance under the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" increases the ceiling on investment insurance and financing under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. It also amends the issuing authority and policy guidance. The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 by changing the issuing authority and policy guidance to increase United States exports and complement trade policy. Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to remove certain sentences and specify key officials including the President of the Corporation, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, and the United States Trade Representative. The amendment to Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 includes adding key officials such as the President of the Corporation, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, and the United States Trade Representative. Additionally, the United States Trade Representative may designate a Deputy to serve on the Board. The President of the United States may designate a Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board from among the Directors, excluding those appointed under specific conditions. TITLE II--TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY

SEC. 201. TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY AUTHORIZATION. Section 661(f)(1)(A) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to authorize $40,000,000 for fiscal 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998.

TITLE III--EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL TRADE ADMINISTRATION

SEC. 301. EXPORT PROMOTION AUTHORIZATION. TITLE III--EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL TRADE ADMINISTRATION

SEC. 301. EXPORT PROMOTION AUTHORIZATION.

Section 202 of the Export Administration Amendments Act of 1985 is amended to authorize $240,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to identify means for providing more coordinated export promotion services to small- and medium-sized businesses and establish priorities for promoting US exports and free market reforms in the Middle East to stimulate job growth. SEC. 402. IMPLEMENTATION OF PRIMARY OBJECTIVES. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will identify and address overlap and duplication in Federal export promotion activities, promote better coordination between State, Federal, and private sector export promotion activities, and share market research data by September 30, 1997. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee aims to improve coordination between State, Federal, and private sector export promotion activities by promoting co-location, cost-sharing, and sharing market research data. This should be included in the annual report by September 30, 1997. SEC. 403. PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT IN THE UKRAINE. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will report on its efforts to promote U.S. trade and investment for private sector development in Ukraine in the 1997 annual report.
